;;Valerie Chiu，14 岁，青少年动物科学家协会主席兼创始人（TADS）是一个由青年领导的非政府组织，致力于促进贫困青年的科学教育。图片：孔日鹏;
;

;2015年，联合国宣布了17项可持续发展目标（SDG），作为解决贫困、饥饿和气候变化等全球问题的综合议程的一部分。这是一个由国际政府联盟组成的组织的举动，但它却引发了一个早熟的五岁香港女孩的新生意识。

;

;七年后，那个女孩瓦莱丽（Valerie）赵咏仪创立了一个由青年领导的非政府组织，名为青少年动物科学家 (TADS)，旨在帮助贫困社区，特别重视科学教育和环境保护。

;

;现在 14 岁的赵和她的组织已经带头开展多项社区活动，包括 6 月 22 日在红磡举行的科学展，教低收入家庭的孩子如何使用家用材料进行实验。

;

;孩子们通过水果、烘焙等有趣的实验学习基本的科学原理苏打水和醋，同时还探索科学与可持续发展之间的联系。

;

;“我们的目标是表明，无论你的背景如何，科学都可以变得容易理解和有趣，”Chiu 说。 “我想让孩子们知道科学就在我们身边，这是他们可以兴奋的事情。”

;
;;
;;Valerie Chiu TADS 是一个由青年领导的组织，其倡议包括举办科学博览会，教低收入家庭的儿童如何使用简单的家居用品进行科学实验。图片：孔日鹏;
;
;

;TADS还通过一项名为“和谐疗愈”的倡议来支持有特殊教育需要的儿童，该倡议结合了音乐、艺术和与动物的互动，以促进

;

;嘉诺撒圣玛丽书院的学生凭借她的努力，入围香港精神奖青年组决赛。

;

;奖项为由《南华早报》和信和集团联合举办的年度活动，旨在表彰其努力可能被忽视的杰出个人或团队。

;

;邱还获得了多项奖学金，包括大湾区杰出学生奖“科学不仅仅是技术——它还涉及联系、创造力和关怀。通过我们的项目，我希望不仅能培养科学好奇心，还能培养社区意识和同情心。”她说。

;
;;
;;< /small>;
;
;

;Chiu 表示，该组织开始超越赋予当地儿童权力的范围，并与希望利用科学作为积极变革工具的海外青年合作。自成立以来，TADS 已吸引了来自 10 多个国家的 130 多名会员。

;

;“我一直着迷于我们可以从其他文化中学到多少东西。今年参加哈佛大学夏令营的经历确实让我大开眼界，让我认识到多元化的观点如何能够增强我们的领导力和研究技能。”她说。

;

;Chiu 感谢她的父母培养了她的好奇心，甚至支持她如果这意味着在很小的时候就分开一段时间。她说：“他们鼓励我追求自己的热情，即使这意味着要走向国际。”

;

;为了扩大 TADS 的影响力，Chiu 说，该组织正在使用社交媒体平台、播客和网络研讨会让全球青年参与有关联合国可持续发展目标的讨论。

;

;展望未来，Chiu 表示，她很高兴能够创办一本杂志并举办科学锦标赛，以继续通过教育和宣传促进平等和可持续发展。

;

; p>;

;“无论我们年龄多大，我们都可以产生影响。重要的是足够关心这个世界并采取行动。我们所有人都有责任创造我们想要生活的未来。”她说。

; Sat, 12 Oct 2024 10:20:01 +0800 Hongkongers living in squalor is a crisis. It’s time to treat it as suchhttps://www.scmp.com/opinion/hong-kong-opinion/article/3281392/hongkongers-living-squalor-crisis-its-time-treat-it-such?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2024.10.12 09:30;
;;
;;插图：Craig Stephens;
;<劏房、笼屋是香港的耻辱。凭借我们的财务纪律、土地出售溢价、税收和稳健的投资，政府多年来积累了大量财政储备，并投资于昂贵的基础设施。

;

;这包括世界一流的国际机场、不断扩大的公共交通和高铁系统、世界上最长的跨海大桥、文化区、邮轮码头、主题公园、新的体育公园和体育场、第三条机场跑道等。我们还在经济刺激、烟花、无人机表演和其他措施上投入了大量资金来重振城市经​​济。

;

;尽管如此，我们还是未能消除大约 110,000 个细分单元来帮助我们最需要帮助的人。不幸的公民。这不是因为缺乏资源或手段，而是因为选择的问题。

;

;长期以来，我们忽视了社会的深层次问题，而将穷人的痛苦和痛苦抛在了脑后。到城市中人迹罕至的黑暗角落。我们相信这样的神话：“如果你长期努力工作，你就能拥有自己的房子”。

;

;穷人被指责工作不够努力，尽管这忽视了缺乏那些出生于弱势生活的人面临的机会和其他障碍。它还忽视了一代又一代积累的结构性住房问题，因此很难将矛头指向任何特定的政府、部门、开发商或个人。

;

;现任政府可能会在这个问题结束时提供一些线索。隧道。行政长官李家超兑现去年施政报告中的承诺，成立专责小组解决劏房问题。

;
;
;

;中央已要求香港在 2049 年（中华人民共和国成立一百周年）之前拆除劏房和笼屋。虽然我们不应该需要北京的法令来唤醒香港同胞的苦难，但直面问题永远不会太晚。

;

;但是，我们真的还需要另外25年吗？这与 SpaceX 首席执行官埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 设想的人类殖民火星并在距离地球 2.28 亿公里的星球上建立一个自给自足的社区的时间框架基本相同。我们并不是在谈论香港的火箭科学，只是让香港不到3%的人口过上体面的生活条件。

;

;显而易见的解决方案是提供足够的公共租赁住房。政府似乎正在采取传统方法，释放新的公共租赁单位，包括轻型公共住房，同时从滥用该制度的人手中收回现有单位，例如不住在那里、在其他地方拥有房产、转租单位以获取利润，或超过资产和收入限制。

;

;与此同时，政府的细分单位工作组正在讨论制定“最低生活条件标准”，包括安全和卫生要求以及最佳居住空间。这将使大多数破旧单位保留一段时间，也许是在标准生效之前的过渡时期。

;
;
;

;这些信息令人困惑。目标是消除劏房和笼屋，还是仅仅对其进行监管？

;

;到目前为止，政府已经采取了一些小步骤，解决了住房问题的边缘——6月底，公共租赁住房的一般申请超过12万份。为细分单位建立“最低标准”只会验证这种做法并使之合法化。鉴于该市租金成本持续居高不下且经济复苏缓慢，这也可能导致更多此类单位涌入市场。

;

;相反，政府应该远离遥远的最后期限，立即撕掉绷带。 ，淘汰劏房和笼屋，避免推卸责任。不难想象下一届政府掌权后会被其他紧迫问题分散注意力。

;

;还记得林郑月娥提出的解决违例建筑工程的倡议，特别是村屋的违例建筑工程，或者她的“明日大屿”想象”？当继任者决定不再继续执行同样的任务时，围绕他们的言论冷却了。

;
;
;

;当香港在 Covid-19 大流行最严重的时候需要隔离患者及其密切接触者时，我们能够在很短的时间内为9个隔离中心提供5万个床位。政府之所以做到这一点，是因为这场大流行被视为一场危机。然而，出于某种原因，我们最贫穷的公民生活在肮脏的条件下并不被视为危机。这是错误的。

;

;与其每月花费 375 万港元（483,000 美元）纳税人的钱来维护现已空置的隔离设施，不如对它们进行消毒、修复和重新组装，作为目前人们的临时住所在细分单位中。该工作组可以利用其资源来确定和重新安置那些最需要体面生活空间的人，而不是花几个月的时间讨论“最低生活条件标准”。

;

;此类单位并不意味着是永久性的，但可以作为租户改善生活的垫脚石。虽然消除劏房和笼屋似乎不太可能产生经济回报，但强大的中产阶级是稳定、富裕社会的引擎，政府完全有动力立即解决这个问题。

;

;让我们期待在人类殖民火星之前很长一段时间消灭所有细分单位和笼舍。比赛开始了。

; Sat, 12 Oct 2024 09:50:02 +0800 China men’s clothing KOL sells a million pairs of trousers using ‘emotional value’https://www.scmp.com/news/people-culture/article/3281774/china-mens-clothing-kol-sells-million-pairs-trousers-using-emotional-value?utm_source=rss_feed

;;中国顶级男装网红销量突破百万为买家创造“情感价值”。图片来源：南华早报综合报道/抖音;
;

;中国一名女主播登上抖音男装销量榜首，引发内地社交媒体热议。

;

;据报道，被称为“高端姐姐”的女士销售了超过100万条男裤。

;

;她运营着一个专注于销售男装的账户矩阵，其中最受欢迎的是KaLanFort高端，总部位于中国南部的广西自治区。

;

;高端姐姐吸引了超过80万粉丝。

;

;据说她的销售策略是通过创造身临其境的、直播中的奇幻场景，让男顾客感觉自己是成功的大亨。

;

;在每个视频中，她都打扮成一位优雅的秘书，穿着合身的西装、短裙，和高跟鞋。

;
;;
;;高端姐姐挑逗男性买家，但也吸引了一些女性追随者。照片：百度;
;
;

;在展示这款裤子时，她将其宣传为高端且非常适合成功男士，尽管其价格为 158 元（22 美元）。< /p>;

;“有地位的成功男士衣柜里一定要有这条裤子，”她说。 “如果你在大城市追求成功，穿这些会提升你的地位并给你面子。”

;

;她的视频和直播中的设置是为了与她的营销策略保持一致而创建的。< /p>;

;她经常在所谓的高端地点拍摄，例如中国南方深圳的中央商务区，周围闪闪发光的摩天大楼，或以豪华汽车经销店为背景。

;

;男模特在她的视频中，佩戴昂贵的配饰来强化物质成功的形象。

;

;当她描述自己销售的产品时，模特可能会看到劳力士手表或玛莎拉蒂钥匙。

;< p>;她还用特技来凸显衣服的实用性。

;

;例如，为了演示裤子的透气性和吸汗性，她会用装满水的茅台酒瓶，将液体倒在裤子上。

;

;她曾经把一条裤子挂在钓鱼竿上，以展示它们有多轻。

;

;为了进一步说服买家，廉价的衣服是高端的，她有时会把它们放在保险箱里，就像奢侈品一样展示。

;

;她的策略是成功的，因为她的六个男装账户总共产生了 435 万元人民币（615,000 美元）的估计销售额根据中国社交媒体评价和大数据分析平台Newrank的数据，7月份她的销售额为875万元。

;

;据报道，她总共卖出了112万条裤子，也吸引了女性崇拜者，她们惊叹不已她致力于每天化着妆不间断地主持数小时的直播。

;
;;
;;成功的影响者使用引人注目的增加在线流量的特技和设置。图片来源：百度;
;
;

;“这些视频我看过好几次了。作为一个女人，我情不自禁地看着他们。它们很引人注目，”一位女士说道。

;

;“她柔和、有节奏的语气很好。难怪她能赚钱。”一位广播系学生说道。

;

;但并非所有反馈都是积极的。

;

;一位观众说：“我发现这些内容迎合了男性的目光。看了几遍，我觉得不舒服，就把她拉黑了。”

;

;“她温柔的声音、紧身的办公室服装和高跟鞋确实吸引了她的目标男性观众。还有谁会对那些购买158元裤子的顾客群体如此温柔、如此用心、如此体贴呢？”另一位说。

; Sat, 12 Oct 2024 09:20:02 +0800 Milton vs Yagi: why do superstorms kill more people in US than China?https://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3282023/milton-vs-yagi-why-do-superstorms-kill-more-people-us-china?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2024.10.12 09:00;
;;
;;佛罗里达州坦帕市中心的一条基本上荒芜的街道周三飓风米尔顿。图片来源：美联社;
;

;今年，中国和美国分别遭受了两次大型热带气旋的袭击。但是，虽然它们的强度相似——其中一个对中国大陆的打击比其他三个更严重——但仍有数百名美国人死亡，而中国则有六人死亡。

;

;热带气旋 - 称为台风或飓风，具体取决于该地区——是世界某些地区常见的威胁。但它们造成的损害因国家而异。

;

;虽然一些差异可以归因于自然，但在确定社区面对毁灭性天气事件的恢复能力时，人为因素也会发挥作用，据专家称。

;

;佛罗里达州在 12 天内遭受了两次强大的热带气旋袭击。三级风暴米尔顿飓风于周三晚上在佛罗里达州萨拉索塔县西耶斯塔岛附近登陆。最新数据显示，至少有 16 人死亡。

;

;9 月 26 日，飓风海伦在佛罗里达州佩里市附近的大本德地区登陆，造成 200 多人死亡。超过一半的死亡人数发生在北卡罗来纳州。

;

;在世界的另一边，超强台风八木于晚间形成后横扫菲律宾、香港、中国南方三省和其他东南亚国家。八月。

;

;八木于 9 月 6 日在海南省文昌登陆时，风速约为 245 公里/小时（152 英里/小时）。相比之下，“米尔顿”在登陆时的风速为 205 公里/小时（120 英里/小时）。佛罗里达州的海伦录得最大持续风速为 220 公里/小时（140 英里/小时）。

;

;八木穿越中国南部时，超过 120 万人受到影响，造成大范围停电和电信服务中断，但相对而言，人员伤亡很少，其中 4 人死亡、95 人受伤。

;

;9 月中旬，上海遭受台风“贝宾卡”袭击，登陆时峰值风速达到 151 公里/小时（94 英里/小时）。地方当局表示，贝宾卡的过境导致江苏省昆山市有两人死亡。

;
;
;

;浙江大学 REN 城市韧性中心主任王乃玉指出，中美两国在应急预警和救援模式上存在差异。

;

;在他自己所在的中国东部沿海省份浙江省，政府部署大量一线工作人员挨家挨户上门救援。台风来袭，确保所有人按要求撤离。

;

;相比之下，美国并没有强制撤离，王说。相反，当局会发出警告，并让居民自己决定是否撤离。

;

;为耶鲁气候连接网站撰稿的气象学家杰夫·马斯特斯表示，在中国，“强制性”实际上意味着强制性，因此风暴袭来时，受到伤害的人数较少。

;

;“美国飓风造成的死亡人数往往更高，因为‘强制’疏散令并不是真正强制性的——多达 40% 的人人们会忽视它，”他说。

;

;中国南方有超过 410,000 人被重新安置，为八木登陆做准备。课程取消，公园关闭，而驻扎文昌的解放军士兵已做好救灾准备。

;

;同样，为了迎接贝宾卡，在其抵达前一天，超过 414,000 人被搬迁，居民也被安置。建议呆在室内。航班、渡轮和火车均暂停。与此同时，2,500多个团队的56,000名救援人员正在待命。

;

;

;;

;

;This is the first in a three-part series delving into the unprecedented challenges China is facing on its road to economic recovery, from inexperience in dealing with such crises to the compounding implications of internal demographic shifts and external trade hurdles.

;

;The topsy-turvy roller-coaster ride that has seen China's economy teetering on the rails for the past four years has left Zack Yao clinging to whatever business he can muster while struggling to determine when the wild ride will end.

;

;At 37 years old, the seller of electric power tools in the eastern province of Zhejiang has never experienced anything like the series of ups and downs that accompanied China's pandemic years and subsequent attempts to return to economic normality.

;

;“I can still feel the sting every time I recall what I went through,” he said. “The memories are fresh.”

;

;He hearkened back to when “everything ground to a halt in early 2020”, leaving him with no revenue for months, followed by a gradual resumption in economic activities and fluctuating earnings as snap lockdowns were imposed under China's adherence to a zero-Covid policy. These included lockdowns from March to June 2022 in Shanghai, which borders Zhejiang to the south.

;

;After restrictive pandemic policies were lifted later that year, glimmering hope appeared at the end of the tumultuous tunnel.

;

;“I was overwhelmed by a sudden spike in orders in the second quarter of 2023 after China opened up and the city I live in launched new projects,” he said. “I rushed to rent a new warehouse and hire more shop assistants.”

;

;But to his dismay, gleaned hope warped into a mirage. The business pickup was short-lived, and the woeful ride resumed.

;

;By the end of last year, his sales had plunged back to those dismal 2020 levels as China's economic malaise took its enduring toll. Yao别无选择，只能削减他可能的费用，包括让员工离开。 Still, his combined losses over the past four years, he says, equate to his total earnings in the five years before Covid.

;

;“What keeps me up at night is I have no idea when the losses are going to end,” he lamented.

;

;Yao's experience is far from unique.他是无数的中国居民之一，感觉到了长期衰退的束缚。 The national economy is facing its sternest test in decades, and the leadership hierarchy in Beijing, while steadfastly determined to press on with an economic transition, has never faced a spiral of such magnitude. Analysts point out that policymakers have no playbook for what has transpired in China, nor does the general public have a comparable frame of reference.

;

;Meanwhile, the growth of China's gross domestic product is a constant cause of concern.在避免停滞，就业和消费者信心的努力中，情况并不顺利。 It is estimated that for every single percentage point of GDP growth in China, about 2 million jobs can be created.

;
;
;

;The youth-unemployment rate, comprising people aged 16 to 24 but excluding college students as of July last year, has been particularly bleak. It reached a post-adjustment high of 18.8 per cent in August – putting nearly one in five young people of employment age out of work.

;

;Also weighing on household and business confidence is the sluggish growth in China's consumer price index – a measure for inflation that has long hovered around 1 per cent, amplifying deflationary pressures.

;

;Meanwhile, shrinking balance sheets across the country were underscored by a contraction of new yuan loans to companies and households in July - the first such contraction in 19 years.

;

;“I've never seen anything like this in my 30-year career,” Li Xunlei, chief economist of Zhongtai Securities, said at an investor conference in September.

;

;“For years, the property market has been plunging – in search of a bottom – with the stock market stuck in bear territory,” added Li, famed for macroeconomic research.

;

;The current crisis is different from the previous storms that China had weathered – namely the high inflation seen in the 1980s, the 1997 Asian financial crisis and the 2008 global financial tsunami – in terms of duration, scale and magnitude, as well as the root cause, according to analysts.

;

;Beijing's swift and resolute actions in the past proved effective in tackling those challenges, but now the unprecedented extended downturn may require a combination of decisive actions, protocols and systematic mechanisms, the pundits have concluded.

;

;“The challenges are on a greater scale today than before, given the weight on the economy created by the property sector and the local government debt burden,” said James Zimmerman, a partner at international law firm Perkins Coie.

;

;“In prior crises, most of the issues were external. Today, the challenges are mainly coming from within,” added Zimmerman, also a former chair of the American Chamber of Commerce in China.

;

;Zhou Zheng, a senior analyst with Zurich-headquartered consultancy China Macro Group, echoed that sentiment in noting how the current challenges are unlike any that have come before.

;

;“Beijing has had its fair share of blunders and missteps in recent years,” Zhou said, pointing to leadership's inexperience in dealing with such calamities.

;

;At the end of the 1980s, pro-market pricing liberalisation, economic overheating, a boom in fixed-asset investment and unchecked monetary supply set inflation alight, and the consumer price index soared 18.8 per cent between 1987 and 1989.

;

;As bank runs and panic buying started to spread, Beijing rushed to slam the brakes on credit supply and axed thousands of infrastructure projects nationwide to arrest surging prices. In a first, the central bank also pledged inflation protections for depositors.

;

;Those measures paid off in the short term, as inflation was defused in 1990, saving the national economy from catastrophe as Beijing pivoted to rekindle sentiment in the aftermath of the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989.

;
;
;

;A few years later, amid the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Beijing promptly launched countercyclical measures and eased fiscal policies to support domestic demand to compensate for slumping exports when its neighbours were embroiled in a financial contagion.

;

;Beijing elevated reforms of the financial sector and state-owned enterprises to the top of its agenda. The People's Bank of China lowered interest rates by half between 1997 and 1999 but withstood the yuan's depreciation pressure.

;

;In around a year, Beijing's measures helped China emerge from the crisis largely unscathed.

;

;Then, in 2008, when the world was engulfed in a financial tsunami, Beijing raced to get ahead of the fallout by unveiling a 4-trillion-yuan stimulus just two months after Western financial markets began to melt down.领导层放弃了早先防止经济过热和通货膨胀的愿望，财政政策变得扩张，预算赤字上限随着发行更多政府债券而提高。 The central bank also trimmed interest rates and reserve-requirement ratios to prop up the battered economy.

;

;“This combination of stimulus and lower rates helped spark a pickup in growth by the second quarter of 2009,” praised the International Monetary Fund in a 2010 report.

;

;However, while that swift action helped mitigate the impact of shock waves from abroad, it left China facing an enormous debt crisis, particularly among local governments and state-owned enterprises.

;

;This time around, Beijing has been much more reserved in its stimulus efforts. A political scientist at Peking University said that, until the stimulus announcement in late September, Beijing spent more than a year beating around the bush amid rising calls to do more for an economy in crisis.

;

;“The [response] slowness was indicative of its inexperience and cluelessness in tackling something as big as this,” said the scholar, who declined to be named as he was not authorised to speak to non-state media.

;
;
;

;Comparisons have also been made between how Beijing has handled the unprecedented challenges and America and Japan's experiences and lessons.

;

;Li Xuenan, a finance professor at the Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business, said that the United States, which is no stranger to economic upheavals, has a mature response mechanism.

;

;“The US has a well-oiled response process formed through losses, experiences and hard-fought lessons as it staggered from one crisis to the next – including the Great Depression,” Li said.

;

;The Great Depression, the first mammoth downturn that the US grappled with, in the 1920s and '30s, marked the establishment of some institutions and policies that have helped the country tide over subsequent crises.

;

;Washington broke with norms and doctrinaire economic theories under President Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal between 1933 and 1938 to salvage the US economy.

;

;Roosevelt fired on all cylinders with proactive monetary policies for the Fed to pump liquidity into the market and scrap the gold standard that allowed the depreciation of the US dollar to stave off deflation. Expansionary fiscal policies also worked in unison, with more government spending and subsidies to households that proved conducive to economic recovery.

;

;The US' policy regime and transmission mechanism, including rate adjustments, have thus been formed in the past世纪。 “Today, the Fed's rate cuts, for instance, can have almost instantaneous effects. This is the envy of many central banks,” Li said.

;

;“In contrast, Beijing still needs to accumulate experience and grow contingency-planning capabilities, and it needs a smooth transmission mechanism to cope with current and future events,” she added.

;

;What is afflicting China also bears striking similarities to Japan's economic difficulties in past decades.

;

;“China's ongoing hardship is acute and may be around for much longer than many may think, as we look at Japan's protracted recession and dissect its lessons,” said the PKU scholar.

;

;Richard Koo, chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute, told the Post in May that, for China to prevail over these deep woes that also bedevilled Japan for years, it needs experience in building resilient economic and societal foundations – something China is still lacking.

;

;“If GDP stays the same and your social structure remains intact and people help each other, then [recession] won't be so bad” as it was in Japan, Koo said. “If the social structure and bond aren't so strong in China, and things start falling apart, it could get much uglier.”

;

;The raft of stimulus policies that Chinese authorities fired off last month included mortgage rate cuts and new tools to boost the stock market. President Xi Jinping also issued a rallying call to Chinese officials in a bid to prevent property from further slumping, and to stabilise growth, marking leadership's most forcible pivot since the pandemic.

;

;However, economists and observers said it may take time to restore confidence among consumers and businesses to the point that it ultimately revives the whole economy.

;
;
;

;One lingering question is whether the shift represents a strategic policy pivot or merely a short-term tactical move.

;

;“Many of the initiatives launched last month are things that economists have [wanted] for years, together with more fundamental reforms that have yet to be initiated,” said Zimmerman at Perkins Coie.

;

;“New stimulus measures are just a tactic. Without a strategy for restoring investor and consumer confidence, it's all for naught.”

;

;But Zhou at China Macro Group said a strategic transition is still under way, albeit slowly.

;

;“There was already the pain from an economy in transition since the 2010s, which Beijing deemed necessary to upgrade industries. Had it not been for the trade war and Covid, the transition and upgrades could have borne enough fruit to put the Chinese economy in a far better shape than it is now,” he stressed.

;

;“The transition, though slowed and more painful, is still ongoing.”

;

;Professor Li at Cheung Kong also deemed September's stimulus tactical, but stressed that Beijing has never lost sight of a strategic transition.

;

;“Last month's stimulus serves as more of a confidence boost,” she explained. “北京不会仅仅依靠货币政策调整或股市来重启经济。 The real deal is always [China's] economic transformation and tech innovation.”

;

;

;A debate over what constitutes a fair wage for Hong Kong's foreign domestic workers has arisen between worker unions and employment agencies after the government announced a salary increase. The minimum wage for foreign domestic workers has increased by HK$120 (US$15) a month to HK$4,990, a 2.5 per cent rise, amid consumer price inflation in the city.

;

;This is lower than the 3 per cent pay rise for civil servants and 4 per cent average increase across the private sector – and smaller than the 3 per cent boost that foreign domestic workers received last year.

;

;The Hong Kong Union of Employment Agencies, however, says the 2.5 per cent increase outstrips the city's inflation rate of 1.7 per cent last year, disagreeing with workers' need to keep up with inflation.

;

;Still, the latest pay increase does not apply to the optional food allowance of at least HK$1,236 a month, or around HK$40 a day. And while the employment contract does not stipulate working hours, domestic workers in Hong Kong are known to have to work long hours.

;

;A survey by the International Organisation for Migration, Migrasia and the University of Hong Kong last year found that 45 per cent worked between 12-15 hours per day, with 20 per cent working anywhere from 16 hours to 20 hours. This translates to hardly HK$20 an hour at the better end and less than HK$10 for the hardest-worked – a mere fraction of the statutory minimum wage of HK$40 an hour.

;

;While caring and domestic work relegated to the private sphere is often invisible and, as a result, undervalued, the Hong Kong government acknowledges the importance of migrant domestic workers to the economy.

;
;
;

;A 2019 Experian study estimated that they contributed HK$98 billion to Hong Kong's economy, amounting to 3.6 per cent of gross domestic product in 2018 and freeing up an additional 30 per cent of mothers to work. It is difficult to argue that the minimum wage for foreign domestic workers should be so low.

;

;In many cases, domestic work is skilled work, including caring for children and the elderly. Hongkongers recognise this and are willing to pay more for those with language proficiency as well as caregiving and first aid qualifications to look after their families.

;

;Migrasia's research shows that 35 per cent of foreign domestic workers earned more than the最低工资。 Salaries can range between HK$5,000-HK$8,000 per month, while some with skills such as driving can command as much as HKD$15,000, according to employment agencies.

;

;It need not be viewed as a zero-sum game where one more dollar paid to your domestic worker is a loss for you; rather, a fair living wage is beneficial to both sides.

;

;A major concern for employers is their domestic worker taking on loans and being in debt. This often originates from recruitment fees, which can be equivalent to several months of the worker's salary, making it hard to save for a rainy day.家庭紧急情况很容易迫使工人借贷。 A fair living wage will allow them to not just keep up with inflation but also comfortably pay their migration costs and tackle any financial emergencies.

;
;
;

;Unlike most Hongkongers, domestic workers have little access to financial services and lines of credit. Experian 研究发现，只有 18% 的人拥有银行账户。 This makes them vulnerable to unscrupulous money lenders, who trick them into loans with excessive interest and harass their employers to collect upon the impossible debts.

;

;To ensure the financial health of domestic workers, it is imperative that their minimum wage be high enough to cover the costs of migration and remittances.家政工人工会呼吁每月至少获得 6,000 港元，他们认为这已经是生活工资了。 This calculation is based on Oxfam Hong Kong's living wage proposal and deducts the cost of food, utilities and rent covered by employers.

;

;An attractive salary and the ability to send money home would also be the single biggest incentive for workers to come to Hong Kong. As we look to the future and consider how we will take care of an ageing population, we must acknowledge that we are competing with other places in the region to attract the domestic workers we need, a demand estimated to rise to 600,000 by 2047.

;

;An investment in the future of Hong Kong requires an investment into providing a living wage for our domestic workers who, after all, do so much behind the scenes to keep our city running.
